topics.title: Supply and Demand: The Two Forces Behind Every Price

hook.text: Why does a bottle of water cost $1 at the store and $6 at an airport? Same water, same bottle.

buildup.text: At the airport, you can't leave to find cheaper water.

discovery.text: Supply and demand: when demand rises or supply falls, prices go up. When supply rises or demand falls, prices drop.

twist.text: During COVID, toilet paper prices spiked not because supply dropped much but because panic buying created artificial.

climax.text: Every price you see â€” gas, rent, coffee â€” is the invisible negotiation between how much exists and how badly people.

punchline.text: The airport knows you have no choice. That's why the water costs $6.

quiz.question: Why does water cost more at an airport?
options: Limited supply and captive demand allow sellers to charge more

topics.title: Opportunity Cost: The Price of Every Choice

hook.text: The cost of going to college isn't just tuition.

buildup.text: Opportunity cost: the value of the next best alternative you give up when you make a choice. Every yes is a hidden no.

discovery.text: A billionaire's opportunity cost of mowing their lawn is enormous. That hour could generate millions.

twist.text: Free things have opportunity costs too. Waiting 2 hours for a free donut costs you whatever else you could have done.

climax.text: Economics isn't about money â€” it's about trade-offs.

punchline.text: The real cost of anything is what you gave up to get it.

quiz.question: What is opportunity cost?
options: The price tag on a product
The value of the best alternative you give up when making a choice

topics.title: Why Diamonds Cost More Than Water

hook.text: Water is essential for life. Diamonds are pretty rocks. Yet diamonds cost thousands while water is nearly free. How?

buildup.text: Adam Smith called this the 'diamond-water paradox.' It baffled economists for a century.

discovery.text: The answer is marginal utility. Water is abundant â€” the next glass adds little value.

twist.text: In a desert, the paradox flips instantly. A glass of water becomes priceless and a diamond becomes a useless rock.

climax.text: Price doesn't reflect total value â€” it reflects the value of one more unit given current supply.

punchline.text: You don't pay for water's value. You pay for how easy it is to get more.

quiz.question: Why are diamonds more expensive than water despite being less essential?
options: Marginal utility: water is abundant so the next unit adds little value, while diamonds are scarce

topics.title: Price Discrimination: Why You Pay More Than the Person Next to You

hook.text: The person in 23B paid $150 for their flight. You paid $450. Same plane, same seat size, same peanuts.

buildup.text: Airlines charge different prices based on when you book, how flexible you are, and how desperately you need to fly.

discovery.text: Price discrimination means charging different customers different prices for the same product based on their.

twist.text: Student discounts, senior pricing, happy hours, and coupons are all price discrimination.

climax.text: If everyone paid the same price, the company either loses cheap customers or leaves money on the table from rich ones.

punchline.text: You don't pay for the product. You pay based on how much the company thinks.

quiz.question: What is price discrimination?
options: Charging different customers different prices for the same product based on willingness to pay

topics.title: Surge Pricing: The Algorithm That Reads Your Desperation

hook.text: It's raining at 2 AM after a concert. Your Uber is 4.7x surge pricing.

buildup.text: Surge pricing adjusts prices in real time based on supply (available drivers) and demand (people requesting rides).

discovery.text: Economically, surge pricing works: higher prices attract more drivers and discourage non-urgent riders.

twist.text: Uber's algorithm surged prices during emergencies â€” hurricanes, terrorist attacks.

climax.text: Surge pricing is efficient but feels unfair.

punchline.text: The most efficient price is often the one that makes people angriest.

quiz.question: Why does surge pricing cause public backlash despite being economically efficient?
options: It feels exploitative because it charges more precisely when people are most desperate and vulnerable

topics.title: The Cobra Effect: When Incentives Backfire

hook.text: Colonial India had too many cobras. The British offered a bounty for dead cobras.

buildup.text: The government designed a rational incentive: kill cobras, get paid. They assumed people would hunt existing cobras.

discovery.text: When the government discovered the breeding farms and cancelled the bounty, breeders released all their cobras.

twist.text: The same happened in Hanoi with rats. Bounties for rat tails led to people cutting tails and releasing rats to breed.

climax.text: The cobra effect: every incentive changes behavior â€” but not always in the intended direction.

punchline.text: If you pay people to solve a problem, make sure you're not paying them to.

quiz.question: What does the 'cobra effect' demonstrate about incentives?
options: People may game incentives in unintended ways that worsen the original problem

topics.title: Moral Hazard: When Insurance Makes You Reckless

hook.text: People with car insurance drive less carefully than uninsured drivers.

buildup.text: Moral hazard: when someone is protected from risk, they take bigger risks. The safety net becomes a trampoline.

discovery.text: Insured homeowners are less likely to install fire alarms. Bailed-out banks take bigger bets. The pattern is universal.

twist.text: Deductibles exist specifically to counter moral hazard.

climax.text: Moral hazard is why complete protection is dangerous. A little skin in the game keeps people responsible.

punchline.text: The safest feeling is often the most dangerous one.

quiz.question: Why do insurance companies use deductibles?
options: To reduce moral hazard by ensuring policyholders still bear some cost of risky behavior

topics.title: The Tragedy of the Commons: Why Shared Things Get Destroyed

hook.text: A shared office fridge is always disgusting. A shared printer always jams. Nobody takes care of what nobody owns.

buildup.text: The tragedy of the commons: when a resource is shared, each person has an incentive to use more and maintain less.

discovery.text: One extra cow on the common pasture benefits the farmer who adds it. But the cost â€” overgrazing â€” is shared by everyone.

twist.text: Ocean fishing follows this exactly. Each boat catches more, but the total fish population collapses.

climax.text: The tragedy of the commons explains pollution, overfishing, traffic congestion, and climate change.

punchline.text: If everyone owns it, nobody protects it.

quiz.question: What causes the tragedy of the commons?
options: Individuals benefit from overusing shared resources while costs are spread across everyone

topics.title: Adverse Selection: Why Used Cars Are Lemons

hook.text: If a one-year-old car is on sale, your first thought is.

buildup.text: George Akerlof showed that in used car markets, sellers know more about the car's quality than buyers.

discovery.text: Good car owners keep their cars. Lemon owners sell. Over time, the used market fills with lemons.

twist.text: Low prices drive away the remaining good cars. The market unravels.

climax.text: Warranties, inspections, and CarFax reports exist to fight adverse selection.

punchline.text: The used car market is full of lemons because lemon owners are the first to.

quiz.question: What is adverse selection in the used car market?
options: Cars break down more when sold
Owners of bad cars are more likely to sell, flooding the market with lemons and driving away good cars
Buyers always choose the cheapest car

topics.title: Externalities: When Your Choices Affect Everyone Else

hook.text: A factory dumps waste in a river. It saves money on disposal. Downstream, fishermen lose their livelihood.

buildup.text: An externality is a cost or benefit that affects someone who didn't choose to be involved.

discovery.text: Positive externalities exist too: your neighbor's garden raises your property value.

twist.text: Markets underproduce positive externalities (education, vaccines) and overproduce negative ones (pollution, noise).

climax.text: Carbon taxes try to fix this: make polluters pay the full cost of their pollution, so prices tell the truth.

punchline.text: The price you pay often doesn't include the cost everyone else bears.

quiz.question: What is an externality?
options: A cost or benefit that affects people not involved in the original transaction

topics.title: The Minimum Wage Debate: Floor or Ceiling?

hook.text: Raise the minimum wage and some economists scream 'job killer!' Others say 'poverty reducer!' Both cite data.

buildup.text: Classical theory: set a price floor above market rate and you create surplus â€” unemployment. Fewer jobs at higher wages.

discovery.text: Card and Krueger studied New Jersey's minimum wage increase.

twist.text: The debate continues because the effect depends on the size of the increase.

climax.text: The minimum wage debate reveals economics' deepest tension.

punchline.text: The minimum wage works â€” until it doesn't. Finding the edge is the hard part.

quiz.question: What did Card and Krueger's study find about minimum wage increases?
options: Employment at fast-food restaurants actually increased after a moderate minimum wage rise

topics.title: The Gig Economy: Freedom or Exploitation?

hook.text: 36% of US workers are gig workers. They have no health insurance, no paid leave, no retirement plan.

buildup.text: Platforms like Uber and DoorDash classify workers as independent contractors.

discovery.text: Gig workers bear all the risk: car maintenance, insurance, fuel.

twist.text: Studies show most gig drivers earn less than minimum wage after expenses.

climax.text: The gig economy is a natural experiment in what happens when labor protections are stripped away.

punchline.text: The gig economy gave workers freedom â€” from benefits, security.

quiz.question: What economic issue does the gig economy highlight?
options: Classifying workers as contractors shifts costs and risks from platforms to workers
Technology has no role in labor markets

topics.title: Why CEOs Earn 300x Their Workers

hook.text: In 1965, US CEOs earned 20x the average worker. Today it's 344x. The job didn't get 17 times harder. So what changed?

buildup.text: One theory: globalization increased the value of top talent.

discovery.text: Another theory: boards set CEO pay, and boards are filled with other CEOs.

twist.text: Studies show no correlation between CEO pay and company performance.

climax.text: CEO pay reflects power dynamics more than productivity.

punchline.text: CEO pay isn't determined by the market. It's determined by the people who set.

quiz.question: What do studies show about the relationship between CEO pay and company performance?
options: Higher pay always means better results
There's no clear correlation â€” the highest-paid CEOs often deliver worse returns

topics.title: Human Capital: Your Most Valuable Investment

hook.text: A college degree adds roughly $1.2 million to lifetime earnings.

buildup.text: Gary Becker coined 'human capital' in 1964: the skills, knowledge, and health that make workers more productive.

discovery.text: Countries that invest in education and healthcare grow faster.

twist.text: But signaling theory argues: degrees don't make you smarter.

climax.text: Whether education builds or signals ability, the return is real. Your brain is the best asset you'll ever own.

punchline.text: The best investment doesn't trade on any exchange.

quiz.question: What is human capital?
options: The skills, knowledge, and health that increase a worker's productivity and earnings

topics.title: Automation Anxiety: Will Robots Take Your Job?

hook.text: The ATM was supposed to kill bank teller jobs.

buildup.text: Every wave of automation â€” looms, tractors, computers â€” triggered panic about mass unemployment.

discovery.text: Automation eliminates tasks, not jobs. When routine tasks are automated.

twist.text: AI is different â€” it automates cognitive tasks, not just physical ones.

climax.text: The question isn't whether robots will take jobs.

punchline.text: Technology has always created more jobs than it destroyed.

quiz.question: What happened to bank teller employment after ATMs were introduced?
options: Employment rose because cheaper branches led to more branches being opened

topics.title: The Subscription Trap: How Companies Lock You In

hook.text: The average American spends $273/month on subscriptions. Most underestimate by 2.5x â€” they think they spend $86.

buildup.text: Subscriptions exploit three biases: status quo bias (you don't cancel).

discovery.text: Companies make signing up easy and canceling hard.

twist.text: Gyms make 50% of revenue from members who never show up.

climax.text: Subscriptions transferred the art of selling from persuading you to buy to preventing you from leaving.

punchline.text: The best subscription business is one where customers forget they're customers.

quiz.question: Why do gyms profit from members who never attend?
options: Status quo bias keeps people paying for unused subscriptions rather than going through the effort of canceling

topics.title: Shrinkflation: The Invisible Price Hike

hook.text: Your favorite chocolate bar didn't get more expensive. It got smaller. Same price, less product.

buildup.text: Shrinkflation: companies reduce product size instead of raising prices.

discovery.text: Toilet paper has fewer sheets. Chip bags have more air. Ice cream went from 2 quarts to 1.5 quarts.

twist.text: It's a rational strategy: studies show a 10% price increase loses more customers than a 10% size reduction.

climax.text: Shrinkflation is inflation in disguise. Official inflation statistics try to capture it, but much slips through.

punchline.text: The stealthiest price increase is the one that doesn't change the price.

quiz.question: Why do companies use shrinkflation instead of raising prices?
options: Consumers notice and react to price increases more than equivalent quantity reductions

topics.title: Dynamic Pricing: The Price That Watches You

hook.text: Amazon changes product prices 2.5 million times per day. The price you see might not be the price someone else sees.

buildup.text: Dynamic pricing uses algorithms to adjust prices based on demand, competitor prices, your browsing history.

discovery.text: Airlines pioneered this: same flight, dozens of prices. Hotels, ride-shares, and e-commerce followed.

twist.text: Research found that searching for flights on a Mac showed higher prices than on a PC.

climax.text: Dynamic pricing is perfect price discrimination powered by big data.

punchline.text: The price tag no longer tells you the price.

quiz.question: How does dynamic pricing differ from traditional pricing?
options: Algorithms adjust prices in real time based on demand, user data, and competitor prices
All customers see the same price

topics.title: The Free Product Illusion: When You're the Product

hook.text: Google is free. Facebook is free. Instagram is free. Together, they earn $500 billion a year.

buildup.text: These platforms sell your attention to advertisers. Every scroll, click, and pause generates data about what you'll buy.

discovery.text: The average American sees 4,000-10,000 ads per day.

twist.text: Facebook's internal research showed Instagram harms teen mental health.

climax.text: When a product is free, you're not the customer â€” you're the inventory being sold to the highest-bidding advertiser.

punchline.text: If you're not paying for it, someone is paying for you.

quiz.question: How do 'free' platforms like Google and Facebook make money?
options: They sell users' attention and data to advertisers

topics.title: Planned Obsolescence: Designed to Break

hook.text: A light bulb in a California fire station has been burning since 1901. Modern bulbs last 1,000 hours. What happened?

buildup.text: In 1924, the Phoebus Cartel of light bulb makers agreed to reduce bulb lifespan from 2,500 to 1,000 hours.

discovery.text: Planned obsolescence: designing products to fail or become outdated so consumers replace them.

twist.text: Apple paid $113 million for secretly slowing old iPhones. They said it preserved battery life.

climax.text: Planned obsolescence drives economic growth but creates massive waste.

punchline.text: The economy grows faster when things break sooner. That's a feature, not a bug.

quiz.question: What was the Phoebus Cartel?
options: Light bulb manufacturers who agreed to reduce bulb lifespan to increase sales

topics.title: The Economics of Tipping: A System Nobody Designed

hook.text: In the US, you tip 20% at restaurants. In Japan, tipping is an insult. In Iceland, it doesn't exist. What's going on?

buildup.text: Tipping was supposed to incentivize good service. Studies show it barely correlates with service quality.

discovery.text: The real economics: tipping lets restaurants pay below minimum wage ($2.13/hr in some U.S. states) and shift labor costs.

twist.text: Research shows tipping is racially biased â€” Black servers receive less regardless of service quality.

climax.text: Tipping is an informal tax that subsidizes restaurant prices. It appears optional but is socially mandatory.

punchline.text: The tip isn't a reward. It's the actual wage your server depends on.

quiz.question: What do studies show about the relationship between service quality and tip size?
options: Better service always means bigger tips
Tip size barely correlates with service quality â€” other factors like weather matter more

topics.title: Why Popcorn Costs $10 at the Movies

hook.text: A bag of popcorn costs 20 cents to make and sells for $10 at the cinema. That's a 4,900% markup. Why would anyone pay?

buildup.text: Movie theaters make almost nothing on ticket sales â€” studios take 70-80% of the ticket price.

discovery.text: Expensive popcorn is a clever pricing strategy.

twist.text: If theaters charged $20 tickets and $3 popcorn, fewer people would come.

climax.text: Movie theaters aren't in the movie business. They're in the snack business with a movie problem.

punchline.text: The movie gets you in the door. The popcorn pays the rent.

quiz.question: Why do movie theaters charge high prices for popcorn?
options: Studios take most ticket revenue, so theaters depend on concession profits to survive
People are willing to pay anything

topics.title: The Economics of Traffic: Why More Lanes Don't Fix Congestion

hook.text: Los Angeles widened the 405 freeway by adding a lane. Traffic got worse. Houston added 23 lanes to the Katy Freeway.

buildup.text: Induced demand: when you make driving easier, more people drive.

discovery.text: Studies show that a 10% increase in road capacity generates roughly 10% more traffic within a few years.

twist.text: The opposite works too. When Seoul demolished an elevated highway, traffic improved. Fewer roads meant fewer drivers.

climax.text: Building more roads to fix traffic is like loosening your belt to fix obesity.

punchline.text: More lanes don't reduce traffic. They create more of it.

quiz.question: What is 'induced demand' in transportation economics?
options: Expanding road capacity attracts additional traffic that fills the new space

topics.title: The Economics of Queuing: Why We Hate Waiting

hook.text: Houston airport had a baggage complaint problem. They sped up bag delivery. Complaints didn't drop.

buildup.text: Passengers now walked 6 minutes to the carousel instead of waiting 6 minutes at it. Same total time.

discovery.text: Occupied time (walking) feels shorter than unoccupied time (standing).

twist.text: Uncertain waits feel longer than known waits.

climax.text: The economics of queuing isn't about reducing wait time â€” it's about reducing the perception of wait time.

punchline.text: The best solution to a waiting problem is making people not realize they're.

quiz.question: How did Houston airport reduce baggage complaints without speeding up delivery?
options: Moved the carousel farther away so passengers walked instead of standing and waiting

topics.title: Why Ice Cream and Crime Both Rise in Summer

hook.text: Ice cream sales and murder rates rise together in summer. Does ice cream cause violence? No.

buildup.text: Correlation means two things move together. Causation means one causes the other.

discovery.text: The hidden variable: heat. Hot weather drives both ice cream sales and outdoor activity.

twist.text: This fallacy fills headlines: 'countries that eat more chocolate win more Nobels!

climax.text: Economics is full of spurious correlations.

punchline.text: Correlation is a clue. Causation is a conviction. Don't confuse the two.

quiz.question: Why do ice cream sales and crime rates rise together in summer?
options: A hidden variable (hot weather) independently drives both outcomes upward

topics.title: The Economics of Matching: Why Markets Need Matchmakers

hook.text: Kidney donors can't sell kidneys. But economist Al Roth designed a system that matches donors and recipients.

buildup.text: Some markets can't use prices â€” organ donation, school admissions, residency matching.

discovery.text: Roth's matching algorithms solve the problem: your kidney goes to my patient, my kidney goes to yours.

twist.text: The same algorithm matches medical residents to hospitals.

climax.text: Not all markets run on prices. Some of the most important ones â€” schools, organs, marriages â€” run on matching.

punchline.text: The most life-saving market in the world doesn't involve a single dollar.

quiz.question: Why can't organ donation use a traditional price-based market?
options: Ethical and legal concerns prohibit selling organs, requiring algorithmic matching systems instead

topics.title: The Economics of Happiness: Can Money Buy It?

hook.text: A famous study said happiness plateaus at $75,000/year. A newer study says it keeps rising. Both are partly right.

buildup.text: Kahneman found emotional well-being plateaus around $75K.

discovery.text: Killingsworth's 2023 study found life satisfaction does keep rising with income.

twist.text: The unhappiest 20% of people see no benefit from income above $100K. For them, money can't fix what's wrong.

climax.text: Money buys happiness indirectly â€” by reducing stress, creating options, and buying time. It's a tool, not a destination.

punchline.text: Money doesn't buy happiness. But poverty doesn't buy anything.

quiz.question: What did recent research find about money and happiness?
options: Happiness keeps rising with income for most people, but not for the already unhappiest 20%

topics.title: Inflation: The Silent Tax on Your Savings

hook.text: A movie ticket cost $0.25 in 1950. Today it's $12.

buildup.text: Inflation means the general price level rises over time. At 3% inflation, prices double every 24 years.

discovery.text: Moderate inflation (2-3%) is considered healthy.

twist.text: Your savings account paying 0.5% while inflation runs at 3% means you're losing 2.5% per year in real value.

climax.text: Inflation is a hidden tax that transfers wealth from savers to borrowers and from workers to asset owners.

punchline.text: Money in a savings account doesn't grow. It slowly dies.

quiz.question: How does inflation affect savings?
options: If inflation exceeds the interest rate, savings lose purchasing power over time
Inflation has no effect on savings

topics.title: The Economics of Gift-Giving: Why Cash Is Efficient but Rude

hook.text: Economist Joel Waldfogel calculated that holiday gift-giving destroys $13 billion in value annually.

buildup.text: From a pure efficiency standpoint, cash is the optimal gift.

discovery.text: But gifts serve a social function beyond economics.

twist.text: Gift cards â€” the compromise between cash and gifts â€” are the most popular present.

climax.text: Gift-giving proves that economic efficiency isn't everything.

punchline.text: An inefficient gift that says 'I know you' beats an efficient one that says 'I.

quiz.question: Why is cash considered the 'efficient' gift by economists?
options: Recipients can buy exactly what they value most, eliminating the value-destroying mismatch of chosen gifts

topics.title: The Economics of Dating: A Market for Love

hook.text: Dating apps are two-sided markets. Tinder has 75 million users competing for attention in a marketplace economists.

buildup.text: Search theory explains dating: you sample options, compare them to a reservation threshold.

discovery.text: The optimal stopping rule (the 37% rule) says.

twist.text: Apps create a paradox of choice: more options reduce satisfaction.

climax.text: Love isn't just economics â€” but the search for it follows patterns economists predicted decades before dating apps.

punchline.text: Economists solved dating in theory. In practice, hearts ignore the math.

quiz.question: What does the 37% rule suggest about dating?
options: Reject the first 37% then pick the next best person
